awd_titl_txt: NYU Materials Research Science and Engineering Center
awd_abstract_narration:
****Nontechnical abstract****
The New York University MRSEC investigates the pathways by which molecules and particles can be organized into materials. One approach emphasizes the role of processing and harnesses new insights that organization need not be orderly, that disorder need not be purely random, and that the materials arising from random organization across multiple scales can have properties surpassing those of crystals. Another seeks to elucidate the mechanisms by which complex molecules crystallize and how defects in crystals can regulate their growth. These activities unite scientists, engineers and mathematicians in an effort to explore materials from the molecular to the macroscopic scale. Their goal is to understand and improve the properties of materials such as food, ceramics, cements, pharmaceutical formulations, organic displays, solar cells, and a host of other technologies, with an eye toward optimizing mechanical strength and fracture resistance, improving the transport of electrons, light or heat, and stabilizing therapeutic agents. The NYU MRSEC operates several programs that benefit K-12 students and the New York City community, exposing students and teachers to materials science concepts, providing summer research programs for high school students, delivering materials science lessons and teacher training on a mobile laboratory, and producing broadcast-quality science videos. The MRSEC operates a summer research program for visiting undergraduates and faculty, largely from four-year colleges and minority-serving institutions. The MRSEC contributes to the acquisition and operation of state-of-the-art instrumentation facilities, including several electron, optical, and holographic microscopies that provide unique capabilities for users at NYU and beyond. The Center expands its impact through a network of national and international collaborators, as well as technology partners and entrepreneurial activities.

****Technical abstract****
The NYU MRSEC unites six NYU Departments and collaborators from key institutions in a project that revolves around two interdisciplinary research groups: Random Organization of Disordered Materials (IRG 1) and Molecular Crystal Growth Mechanisms (IRG 2). IRG 1 investigates how systems driven out of equilibrium evolve towards absorbing states in which dynamic rearrangement ceases, exploring the structures and correlations that arise in granular, multicomponent and active materials under external and internal driving, particularly those of the absorbing states. A key goal is the optimization of material properties such as yield strength and photonic band structure, and the development of active materials such as optically reconfigurable colloids and active extensile viscoelastic liquids. IRG 2 investigates the fundamental science of molecular crystal growth, an area of vital interest for pharmaceuticals, organic electronics, and other technologies. The IRG advances the understanding of essential aspects of crystal growth science and engineering, investigating nucleation, dislocation generation and structure, multi-step assembly at the unit cell level, and origins of non-classical morphologies in molecular crystals. IRG 2 combines theoretical modeling, computer simulation, and experiment to develop predictive models of crystal structure and free energy and to investigate the dynamic aspects of crystal growth.

por.por_cntn:
The Center united investigators from Chemistry, Physics, Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, Electrical Engineering, Biology, and Biomaterials in a program encompassing two Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs) - Driven and Active Matter and Molecular Crystal Growth Mechanisms - a Seed component that fosters innovation and capitalizes on a growing entrepreneurial culture, and a comprehensive education program that captures learners at all levels. The Center produced 322 publications, 14 patents, catalyzed the founding of four start-up companies, and profoundly influenced the NYU culture of team-oriented research and STEM education.

IRG 1 investigated principles related to structure correlations that arise in active materials under external and internal driving, ranging from optically reconfigurable designer colloids, to swimmers, and active extensile viscoelastic liquids. Programming the sequence of assembly of constituents creates complex architectures across length scales. Understanding and controlling self-organization in these materials yields both general principles and practical protocols for optimizing key material properties, from yield strength to photonic band structure. 

IRG 2 investigated processes underlying the self-assembly of molecules into crystals. Crystallization can be complicated by dissymmetric building units, internal dynamics of the molecular components and weak intermolecular forces, all of which limit the predictive synthesis of materials that underlie pharmaceuticals and organic electronics. Essential aspects of crystal growth science and engineering advanced by IRG 2 include structure prediction, nucleation, dislocation generation, and the mechanical origins of non-classical morphologies. This research led to the discovery of diverse new phases of molecular compounds, ranging from common pharmaceuticals, through twisted crystals, to organic semiconductors and contact insecticides. 

The Center grew a robust Education and Human Resources program, consisting of initiatives spanning all levels, from the K-12 sector, through graduate students and postdocs, to undergraduates and faculty, all configured with the aim of growing and sustaining a competitive technical workforce. Residing in the largest, most diverse public school system in the US, the Center was ideally positioned to advance STEM education and public awareness. Several initiatives - the Scientific Frontiers Program (SFP) hosting K-12 students and teachers, research collaboration with high schools, the Biobus delivering science engagement and teacher training on wheels, and the BioBase, a STEM outreach center located in Harlem - sparked interest in STEM among thousands of students in NYC every year, the majority being from underrepresented and economically disadvantaged groups. Since 2014, the NYU-MRSEC has reached over 5,500 participants, including K-12 students, undergraduates and members of the general public. 

The SFP introduced new hands-on curricula deriving from the Center?s research interests (Hands-on Polymers Science, Electrochemistry, Clean Energy). The Center shared its excitement with crystals through its program K-16: Crystal Growing Mania, and it partnered with NYC schools to prepare students for the US Crystal Growing Competition. Center investigators along with undergraduate students from CSTEP (Collegiate New York State Science and Technology Entry Program), staffed the Center?s interactive booth at the World Science Festival and the NYC March for Science, reaching between 500 and 1000 members of the general public annually, presenting hands-on demonstrations related tocrystallization, microscopy, and properties of matter.

The Center created multiple BioBus curriculum moduli including the DIY Microscope which spawned a series of workshops on DIY holographic microscopy, during which participants built working microscopes and used them to observe iridescent colloidal crystals and bacteria. This module reached 300 students from 5th-12th grades in 2019 alone, its inaugural year. NYU MRSEC investigators also collaborated with BioBus staff to create a food-based materials science module. The Center hosted week-long BioBus Summer Camps in which students conducted experiments along with MRSEC investigators. 

The Center operated a REU program that has leveraged the Faculty Resource Network, a NYU-based organization with connections to more than 50 minority-serving institutions, and CSTEP, a program providing mentorship for NYU minority STEM groups and financially disadvantaged students. The Center has developed a strong relationship with the University of Puerto Rico-Rio Piedras (UPR), hosting numerous UPR students, as well as Faculty-Student Teams in the summers. The Center also facilitated research experiences for NYU undergraduates through the MRSEC Emerging Scientist Research Program, an innovative program aimed at providing mentorship and research experience to NYU minority STEM groups and financially disadvantaged students affiliated with the CSTEP program, and MRSEC Education Fellowships, a K-12 educational initiative in which undergraduate students develop "Lab Lessons", a series of electronic pre-lab modules for high school chemistry students.
